title: SoK: On the Impossible Security of Very Large Foundation Models

last_post.content:
On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

title: How Paris Pulled Off What New York and London Can Only Dream About

last_post.content:
When I lived in #Paris in the 1990s, it was a paradise for drivers, hell for cyclists and pedestrians.

Over the years, I've seen it become more like #Amsterdam and #Copenhagen

Henry Grabar explains how they pulled it off...

"How Paris Kicked Out the Cars
A city once remade for voitures has transformed itself into an unlikely utopia for cyclists and pedestrians. What can it teach us?"

https://slate.com/business/2023/03/paris-car-ban-bikes-cycling-history-france.html

Checkout our newest work: Self-Refine: Iterative Refinement with Self-Feedback

We show that LLMs such as GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 can:
1. Generate a draft output
2. Generate textual feedback critiquing it
3. Refine the draft output using the feedback
4. Iterate, as needed

Improves performance on 7 tasks including code and creative text generation. No supervised training, no RL, no human feedback!

Led by Aman Madaan
PDF: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.17651.pdf
Project page: https://selfrefine.info

54 years ago today, the brilliant & delightful Steve Crocker, then at UCLA, circulated to the nascent Network Working Group a "Request for Comment" about Host Software. This was #RFC 1, the first of what are now 9411 technical documents defining (and ever evolving) the Internet as we know it.

To me, the Internet is the RFC series, even more than the computers that implement them.

So: Happy 54th birthday, Internet!

https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc1

title: Twitter has outsized influence, but it doesn’t drive much traffic for most news orgs, a new report says

last_post.content:
I think people need to understand that Twitter is not a major driver of traffic for most news organizations.

The reason why news organizations are on twitter is because reporters and editors are on it, and it's useful as a tool to get in touch with certain types of folks.

News orgs can leave twitter because it's not critical for them.

(see https://www.niemanlab.org/2016/04/twitter-has-outsized-influence-but-it-doesnt-drive-much-traffic-for-most-news-orgs-a-new-report-says/ )

title: Putin's Twitter account resurfaces as Russia comes in from the cold

last_post.content:
Over on the bad site, Twitter has lifted restrictions on Kremlin accounts and is no longer limiting the reach of Kremlin media accounts.

Russian government tweets are appearing in Twitter’s algorithmically-driven “For You” feed for newly created accounts, even when they did not follow them. So Twitter is not just *showing* these Kremlin accounts — it's algorithmically *boosting* them.

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2023/04/07/elon-musk-twitter-lifts-restrictions-putin-kremlin-russia/

Machine learning can easily produce false positives when the test set is wrongly used. Just et al in
@NatureHumBehav suggested that ML can identify suicidal ideation extremely well from fMRI and we were skeptical. Today retraction and our analysis of what went wrong came out.

Here is the retracted paper: https://nature.com/articles/s41562-017-0234-y and here is our refutation https://nature.com/articles/s41562-023-01560-6. If true, the paper's approach could revolutionize psychiatric approaches to suicide.

So what went wrong? The authors apparently used the test data to select features. Obvious mistake. A reminder for everyone into ML: never use the test set for *anything* but testing. Only practical way to do so in medicine? Lock away the test set till algorithm is registered.

Side note: it took 3 years to go through the process of demonstrating that the paper went wrong. Journals need procedures to accelerate this. Also, all the good things of this were by
@tdverstynen

New blog post! I wrote about Wuzzo Goes on Holiday, an incredibly charming children's storybook game for the CD-i. It follows an anthropomorphic bird named Wuzzo as he completely blunders the start to his vacation.

Wuzzo was never released, and there's almost nothing written about it anywhere online, but I was able to track down a number of its developers to bring you the definitive story behind how it was made and why it never came out.

https://cdrom.ca/games/cd-i/unreleased/2023/04/07/wuzzo.html

title: Do we misremember Eternal September?Kevin Driscoll / University of virginia – Flow

last_post.content:
Inspired by the last few months on fedi, three provocations about (mis)remembering Eternal September:

1️⃣ AOL's gateway didn't open in Sept 1993 (it was Feb 1994)
2️⃣ AOL was not the only service to frustrate USENET (people grumbled about FidoNet, CompuServe, etc)
3️⃣ USENET of 1994 was hardly a utopia (the hostility to AOL users far outweighed the disruption they caused)

This is just a kernel of an idea. Happy to hear your thoughts!

🔗 Read on in the latest issue of Flow:
https://www.flowjournal.org/2023/04/eternal-september/

#chemistry #water #hydrology
#science #librarian

Checkout our newest work: Self-Refine: Iterative Refinement with Self-Feedback

We show that LLMs such as GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 can:
1. Generate a draft output
2. Generate textual feedback critiquing it
3. Refine the draft output using the feedback
4. Iterate, as needed

Improves performance on 7 tasks including code and creative text generation. No supervised training, no RL, no human feedback!

Led by Aman Madaan
PDF: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.17651.pdf
Project page: https://selfrefine.info

title: FSW 2023 : Day 3 - Remote Work: the Good, the Bad, the Ugly, and the Way Forward

last_post.content:
What happened to the future of work? My keynote about REMOTE WORK from 2 weeks ago. TL;DR:
1. After 40 years of research into what makes remote work succeed …
2. … the pandemic era was a parade of catastrophic “worst hits”!
3. But our workplaces are broken, so workers don’t want to go “back”
4. Fixing these problems can help us move forward to a better “future of work”
